title: 103_hr4828
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Bombing Prevention Act". The Congress finds that the number of criminal bombing incidents in the United States has doubled since 1988, with hundreds of millions of pounds of explosives purchased without permits. One-third of bombs used in crimes contain black powder or smokeless powder. The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and Pan Am Flight 103 highlight the dangers of bomb attacks. Effective regulation of interstate commerce in explosives requires changes in the regulatory framework due to the diverse nature of explosive materials. The Congress recognizes the need for stricter regulation of explosives transactions to protect the safety and property of the citizenry and vital infrastructure for interstate and foreign commerce. SEC. 101. PERMITS FOR PURCHASE OF EXPLOSIVES. Section 842 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to regulate the transportation, distribution, and receipt of explosive materials. The amendments apply to conduct after an 18-month period from the enactment of the Act. Regulations must be established within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue final regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment regarding the transportation, distribution, and receipt of explosive materials. States will be notified of the regulations to consider revising their explosives laws. SEC. 102 amends Section 843(a) of title 18, United States Code by adding requirements for license applicants and fees. Each license fee shall not exceed $300, and each permit fee shall not exceed $100. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the national instant criminal background check system to investigate license or permit applicants under chapter 40 of title 18, United States Code. Additionally, there are requirements for purchases of black powder and smokeless powder. SEC. 104 amends Section 845 of title 18, United States Code, regarding purchases of black powder and smokeless powder. The amendment includes limitations on quantities for commercially manufactured black powder and smokeless powder. SEC. 105 introduces enhanced penalties. SEC. 105 enhances penalties for violations of certain provisions in title 18, United States Code, to align them with penalties for similar violations in another chapter. Section 844(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow for the destruction of explosive materials seized for forfeiture if it is impracticable or unsafe to store them. Destruction must be witnessed, and the owner can apply for reimbursement within 60 days. The owner of seized explosive materials can apply for reimbursement equal to the fair market value if the seizure was wrongful. SEC. 107. FORFEITURE OF INSTRUMENTALITIES OF EXPLOSIVES OFFENSES. Amends civil and criminal forfeiture laws to include property involved in explosive materials violations or conspiracies. TITLE II--PLASTIC EXPLOSIVES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS. Section 841 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include definitions related to the Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives and Detection agents like Ethylene glycol dinitrate (EGDN) and 2,3-Dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane (DMNB). The amended Section 841 of title 18, United States Code includes definitions for specific substances in explosives, such as C6H12(NO2)2, p-MNT, o-MNT, and other substances specified by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense. These substances must meet minimum concentration requirements in finished explosives as outlined in the Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives. The amended Section 841 of title 18, United States Code defines "Plastic explosive" as an explosive material in flexible sheet form with high explosives and a binder, malleable at room temperature. SEC. 202. REQUIREMENT OF DETECTION AGENTS FOR PLASTIC EXPLOSIVES. Section 842 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to make it unlawful to manufacture or import/export plastic explosives without a detection agent. Exceptions are made for explosives imported or manufactured before the effective date of the subsection by certain agencies. It is illegal to possess plastic explosives without a detection agent after the Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives comes into effect in the United States. There are exceptions for explosives imported, brought in, or manufactured before the effective date of the subsection by certain agencies. It is unlawful for anyone, except certain government agencies, to possess plastic explosives without reporting details to the Secretary within 120 days of the effective date of the subsection. SEC. 203 amends Section 844(a) of title 18, imposing criminal sanctions for violating specific sections of section 842, including fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years. SEC. 204 provides exceptions. Section 845 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include an affirmative defense for proceedings involving subsections (l), (m), (n), or (o) of section 842 if the defendant proves by a preponderance of the evidence that the plastic explosive was intended for lawful research, development, testing, or training in explosives detection. The plastic explosive can be used for training in explosives detection, development, or testing of explosives detection equipment, or for forensic science purposes. It can also be incorporated in a military device within the United States for military or police functions. The term "military device" includes various explosive devices like shells, bombs, missiles, grenades, etc., manufactured for military or police purposes. SEC. 205. INVESTIGATIVE AUTHORITY amended to give the Attorney General authority over violations by terrorist or revolutionary groups. SEC. 206. Effective date of amendments is 1 year after enactment of the Act.
